headline: Biden and Trump agree to 2 presidential debates, with first set for June 27 on CNN
content: Washington CNN — President Joe Biden and former President Donald Trump have both accepted an invitation from CNN to debate on June 27, a historically early showdown that will set the tone for the final months of the 2024 campaign. “I’ve received and accepted an invitation from @CNN for a debate on June 27th. Over to you, Donald. As you said: anywhere, any time, any place,” Biden said in a post on X. Trump later told CNN’s Kaitlan Collins, “The answer is yes, I will accept.” Later Wednesday morning, both men said they had accepted an invitation from ABC to hold a second debate on September 10. The news is the latest development in a quickly escalating tit-for-tat over debates between the two political rivals. Biden’s campaign earlier called on Trump to join him for two presidential debates hosted by news organizations and formally informed the Commission on Presidential Debates that the president will not participate in its previously scheduled fall debates. The former president quickly said he was on board with earlier debates and told radio host Hugh Hewitt that he would accept any moderator. Biden only recently said that he was happy to debate Trump, though he was non-committal on the format of such a debate, telling radio host Howard Stern, “I’m happy to debate him.” In a social media video and a subsequent letter to the Commission on Presidential Debates, Biden’s campaign laid out its proposed terms, including possible debate dates in June and September.

headline: Scientists Discover New Planet
content: A team of astronomers has discovered a new planet orbiting a distant star. The planet, which is about twice the size of Earth, is located in the habitable zone of its solar system, meaning it could potentially support life.

headline: Scientists Develop New Battery Technology with Ten Times the Capacity
content: A team of researchers from Stanford University has developed a new battery technology that offers ten times the energy storage capacity of current lithium-ion batteries. This breakthrough could revolutionize electric vehicles, renewable energy storage, and portable electronics. The new battery design uses a novel electrode material that allows for a significantly higher density of lithium ions to be stored. This leads to a much longer battery life and faster charging times. The researchers are currently working on scaling up the production process for this new battery technology and hope to bring it to market within the next few years.

headline: International Talks Resume on Iran Nuclear Deal
content: After a months-long hiatus, representatives from Iran and the P5+1 group of nations (the United States, United Kingdom, France, China, Russia, and Germany) have resumed talks in Vienna aimed at reviving the 2015 Iran nuclear deal. The deal, which was formally known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), was designed to limit Iran's nuclear program in exchange for the lifting of economic sanctions. However, the deal began to unravel in 2  after the United States withdrew from it under the Trump administration. The Biden administration has signaled its willingness to rejoin the JCPOA, but significant challenges remain, including how to address Iran's advancements in its nuclear program since 2019 and how to ensure long-term compliance with the deal's terms.

headline: Local Artist Wins Renowned National Painting Competition
content: Kharkiv-based artist, Olena Petrova, has been awarded the prestigious Grand Prize in the National Art Competition. Her winning piece, titled 'Sunflowers of Hope,' captivated the judges with its vibrant colors and powerful message of resilience. Petrova's work depicts a field of sunflowers blooming amidst the ruins of a war-torn landscape. The sunflowers, a national symbol of Ukraine, represent hope and perseverance in the face of adversity. Petrova's win is a major recognition of the Kharkiv art scene and a source of inspiration for aspiring artists across the country.

headline: Historic Vote: City Council Approves Public Transportation Expansion Plan
content: In a landmark decision, the Kharkiv City Council has voted to approve a comprehensive public transportation expansion plan. The plan includes the construction of new subway lines, bus rapid transit routes, and streetcar extensions. It also aims to improve the frequency and reliability of existing services. The expansion plan is expected to significantly reduce traffic congestion, improve air quality, and make public transportation a more attractive option for residents. The project is expected to be completed in phases over the next decade and will be funded through a combination of public and private investment.

headline: Archaeologists Uncover Ancient Artifacts in Eastern Ukraine
content: A team of archaeologists working in eastern Ukraine has unearthed a trove of ancient artifacts that shed new light on the region's history. The artifacts, which date back to the Scythian period (7th-3rd centuries BCE), include weapons, jewelry, and pottery. The Scythians were a nomadic people who inhabited the Eurasian steppe and were known for their horsemanship and warfare skills. The discovery of these artifacts is significant because it provides new insights into the Scythian culture and their way of life. It also suggests that the region may have been a more important center of trade and commerce than previously thought.

headline: Archaeologists Discover Ancient Temple Complex in Eastern Ukraine
content: A team of Ukrainian archaeologists working in eastern Ukraine has unearthed a vast complex of temples dating back to the Scythian era. The Scythians were a nomadic people who inhabited the Eurasian steppe from the 7th century BC to the 4th century AD. The newly discovered complex is located near the village of Stanytsia Luhanska, in the Luhansk region. It consists of several large temples, as well as smaller buildings that may have been used for housing or storage. The archaeologists believe that the complex was a major religious center for the Scythians. They are currently working to date the site more precisely and to determine the function of the various buildings. This discovery is sure to shed new light on the Scythians' religion and culture.

headline: Ukrainian Startup Develops Innovative Water Purification System
content: A Ukrainian startup has developed a new water purification system that could revolutionize access to clean water in developing countries. The system, called WaterGen, uses a solar-powered process to remove contaminants from water. It is compact, portable, and easy to use, making it ideal for use in remote areas. WaterGen has already been successfully tested in several countries, including Kenya and Haiti. The company is now working to scale up production and make the system more affordable. If successful, WaterGen could help to provide millions of people with access to clean water for the first time. This innovation has the potential to improve public health and sanitation in many parts of the world.
